Award.AwardTitle: Atom Transfer Radical Polymerization of Acidic Monomers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Radical polymerization is a chemical reaction that sequentially adds together small molecules (called monomers) to form long polymer chains that consist of hundreds or thousands of repeating units. Radical polymerization is a powerful synthetic method. It is used to make nearly half of all polymers (plastics), about 100 million tons worldwide each year. Atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) is a special type of radical polymerization that can prepare polymers with precisely controlled chain lengths. In addition, depending on the chemical structure of the monomer, it can produce a variety of shapes, such as stars, combs, brushes or rings and each of these has specialty applications. While ATRP is a common technique, some monomers, especially those with acidic functionalities, are difficult to polymerize using ATRP. Polymers formed from acidic monomers are desirable because they have unique properties that make them useful in a variety of applications. With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Matyjaszewski at Carnegie Mellon University is developing ATRP methods for the controlled polymerization of acidic monomers. The project, which could enable the creation of new commercially-scaled plastics that benefit society, trains undergraduate and graduate students in polymer science. The research team also works with members of the Controlled Radical Polymerization (CRP) Consortium at Carnegie Mellon University to develop new materials for use in a range of industrial markets.

The intellectual challenge of this research comprises understanding, improving, and expanding direct ATRP of acidic monomers without neutralization or protection. Controlled ATRP of acidic monomers requires a fundamental understanding of the kinetics and thermodynamics of ATRP and the associated side reactions. New copper catalyst complexes are developed to achieve higher selectivity and stability under acidic conditions. Iron catalysts and metal-free organic photoredox catalysts are studied to further reduce an environmental impact of ATRP. New synthetic pathways are explored to economically produce acidic polymers by direct ATRP of unprotected monomers. The new polymers with well-controlled complex architectures, including organic-inorganic hybrids such as nanocomposites, functionalized surfaces, and bioconjugates are of both academic and commercial importance. The process saves time and energy and reduces cost in academic and industrial laboratories. The results of this research are disseminated through Professor Matyjaszewski's website, timely publications, student presentations at (inter)national conferences, and through the industrial CRP Consortium at Carnegie Mellon University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project were to polymerize acidic monomers by Atom Transfer Radical Polymerization (ATRP) and to provide better external control of ATRP with parts per million catalysts. ATRP is an important method for synthesis of well-defined polymers and is already commercially used by several companies world-wide. Therefore, it is critically important to enhance efficiency of the polymerization process and expand the range of polymerizable monomers. The intellectual merit included development of conditions for direct efficient polymerization of acrylic and methacrylic acids. In contrast to earlier reports, the most efficient ATRP was accomplished at low pH (~ 1.5) with pyridine-based ligands. Interestingly bio-based mesohemin catalysts were also very efficient. The project encompassed computational modeling, kinetic and mechanistic studies, and polymer synthesis and characterization. Excellent spatial and temporal control was achieved using light, electrical current, and mechanical forces as external stimuli. The most active ATRP catalysts exhibited not only high affinity for alkyl halides but also for radicals yielding organometallic species. The research carried out had a broader impact on other disciplines. The polyacrylic and polymethacrylic acids are important commercial polymers with applications ranging from antifouling, scale resistant, surfactant and biomedical areas. Direct polymerization of these monomers reduced number of derivatives and enhanced green aspects of ATRP. Temporal control provided safer and more benign process conditions. The project involved education of graduate, undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows. They were exposed to the most recent and advanced synthetic techniques in radical polymerization processes and characterization of polymeric materials. They regularly presented at semiannual Consortium meetings and also at national and international symposia. Their research was recognized by several awards and they started successful careers in either academia or industry. PI was recognized by ACS award in Chemistry of Materials and Paul Flory Polymer Education Award (2020). He was elected to National Academy of Sciences and to Australian and European Academy of Sciences. The main dissemination process was through timely publications: 48 papers were published in peer-review journals. Our web site was visited annually over 50,000 times and provides introductory and advanced information on controlled radical polymerization systems. The ACS Meeting on Controlled Radical Polymerization was organized in 2017 with ca. 100 oral and 100 poster presentations.  Controlled radical polymerization is of significant commercial interest as evidenced by 60 international companies that have participated at the industrial consortium at Carnegie Mellon and 17 signed licenses resulting in new products commercialized in US, Europe and Japan. During Covid19 lab shut down Matyjaszewski group members organized a series of webinars with over 3000 participants from the entire world, inviting 11 senior polymer chemists and 11 postdocs and graduate students to present cutting edge polymer science.
